awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Synergizing Braille and Science: Real-time Accessibility of Tactile Graphics in Laboratory Settings for Blind and Low Vision (BLV) Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to increase the participation of the underrepresented population of blind and low vision (BLV) persons in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.  Through a novel assistive technology that provides BLV individuals with multisensory access to scientific data in real time, this technology will enable access  on par with sighted peers. BLV students, unlike their sighted peers, lack independent access to real-time scientific data whether in the laboratory or in the field. This inaccessibility either precludes their full participation in hands-on science inquiry, or leaves them dependent on sighted peers to access real-time data. With this project, BLV students across K-12 and post-secondary institutions, as well as BLV scientists and others interested in STEM, will benefit from a tool that makes it possible for them to work independently in laboratory situations. This innovation will make science laboratory learning and laboratory workplaces more inclusive and equitable for the blind and low vision individuals.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on developing a 2-dimensional, hand-held, portable, refreshable Braille and tactile graphics scientific data collection tool that can be used to collect quantifiable data in real time using wireless sensors. Blind and Low Vision (BLV) students are as capable as their sighted peers in STEM yet, unlike their sighted peers, lack independent access to real-time scientific data in the laboratory. This effort seeks to address this inequity by leveraging the expertise of blind scientists and pioneers in STEM access technology to iteratively develop a interative versions of novel, blind-accessible innovations which will give BLV students, scientists and others access to quantitative data collected in the laboratory or in the field. This innovation will be optimized for the BLV by documenting usability concerns and making the necessary modifications to hardware and source-code prior to field-testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Students with blindness or low vision (BLV) are underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) degrees and employment. Inaccessibility of lab equipment results in students with BLV at all educational levels being relegated to the role of passive observer, unable to participate fully in the hands-on components and real-time data analysis of experiments. Independence Science, LLC, through previous National Science Foundation Small Business  Innovation Research (NSF/SBIR) Phase I and II awards 0945481 and 1127412, developed and commercialized the Talking LabQuest, which provides a text-to-speech (TTS) interface for LabQuest devices from Vernier Science Education (VSE) based in Beaverton, Oregon that enables students with BLV to independently collect data with VSE sensors. However, students with BLV are not able to access tabular and graphical representations of data in real time, and must rely solely on audio for access to data collection.

With our current SBIR award, Independence Science, located in West Lafayette, Indiana, developed a proof-of-concept app With the programming expertise of EQWare located in Oregon City, Oregon, to connect to and control a prototype multi-line braille display from Tactile Engineering based in Lafayette, Indiana and Vernier Science Education?s sensors. Because there has never been a commercially available dynamic multi-line braille display, there are many open questions about how the user interface should function and how real-time graphing of data and updating of data tables for scientific sensors should work. As part of our research, we endeavored to answer some of these questions.

The app runs on Android tablets and connects to VSE?s Go-Direct Bluetooth sensors using their software development kit and connects to the prototype multi-line braille display also via Bluetooth.  The app allows the user to collect data from the Go-Direct sensors. The braille display is used for all input and output, and the app handles all input processing, output generation, and carries out all functionality. From the discoverable sensors, the user can select and connect to the desired Vernier sensor, set experimental parameters, collect data, update and display the table and graph of the data as it is being collected, and display the tabular and graph data after data collection has ended.

Drawing on the experience of our team of blind scientists, we designed the user interface of the Sci-Dot including for the displaying and live updating of a tactile graph of data during collection. After the proof of concept had been developed and internally tested, we conducted a user study with the Sci-Dot through a consumer organization where individuals with BLV participated. They provided us with valuable feedback regarding the design and functionality of the Sci-Dot, including areas that could use improvement. They were able to collect data and interpret the tactile graph of the data as it was being collected. They were all enthusiastic about the opportunities that the Sci-Dot will provide to students with BLV in STEM. One participant said, ?I just love seeing how I could scale the different curves and I could get a picture of what was going on,? and another participant validated all of our effort with ?This is so cool y'all, oh my gosh. I wish I had this when I was in school.?

In sum, Independence Science has proven that scientific data acquisition is technically feasible via the development of the Sci-Dot, a multiline, refreshable, braille and tactile graphics logger capable of data collection and analysis fed through data measurement probes in laboratory settings where data output in visual formats is the norm. Thus, the Sci-Dot is a transformative tool that has the potential to provide equitable experiences for students with BLV interested in pursuing STEM careers.
